did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: A Guide to the Executive Papers of Governor John G. Pollard, 1930-1934
did.origination: Pollard, John G., Records of Virginia Governor

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Virginia. Governor (1930-1934 : Pollard). Executive Papers of Governor John G. Pollard, 1930-1934. Accession 23344a, State government records collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Virginia.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Accession 23344a transferred from the Office of the Governor, 1946 January and May.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: John Garland Pollard (1871-1937) served as attorney general of Virginia 1914-1918, and Governor of Virginia 1930-1934. He was married to Violet MacDougall Pollard (d. 1977) and is buried at Hollywood Cemetery, Richmond, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Executive Papers of Governor John G. Pollard are housed in 164 boxes. The collection is arranged into six (6) series. Series have been designated for: I. General Correspondence. II. Miscellaneous Correspondence. III. Delegates Appointed. IV. Penal Affairs. V. Financial Records. VI. Personal. These records include applications, appointments, correspondence, extraditions, invitations, pardons, proclamations, reports, and requisitions. These records document the gubernatorial administration of John G. Pollard, 15 January 1930 to 16 January 1934.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series:

scopecontent.p: The General Correspondence series, 1930-1934 is housed in one hundred and twenty-three archival boxes and is arranged alphabetically by subject. This series documents correspondence received and sent by Governor Pollard during his four-year term as governor of Virginia. In addition to correspondence, there are reports, proclamations, telegrams, orders, resolutions, acts, publications, news clippings, invitations, proceedings, financial statements, invoices, and other sundry items. Topics include Addresses and Statements, Adjutant General, Agriculture and Immigration, Apple Blossom Festival, Appointments, Art Commission, Attorney General, Budget, Buildings and Grounds, Busts in Rotunda, Conservation and Development, Corporation Commission, Education, Federal Affairs (Civilian Conservation Corps, Emergency Relief, Public Works, Reconstruction Finance Corporation), Fisheries, General Assembly, Highways, Invitations, Judges, Law Enforcement, Motor Vehicles, Penitentiary, Proclamations, Prohibition Department, Purchasing and Printing, Reorganization of State Government, State Art Museum, State Seal, Taxation, Unemployment, George Washington (Bicentennial Birth Commission), and Yorktown Sesqui-centennial Commission.

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous Correspondence series, 1930-1934 is housed in seven archival boxes and is arranged alphabetically by subject. This series documents correspondence received and sent by Governor Pollard during his four-year term as governor of Virginia. In addition to correspondence, there are reports, proclamations, telegrams, orders, resolutions, acts, publications, news clippings, invitations, proceedings, financial statements, invoices, and other sundry items.
The Delegates Appointed series, 1930-1934 is housed in four archival boxes and is arranged alphabetically by name of association or conference.

scopecontent.p: The Penal Affairs series, 1930-1934 is housed in twenty-four archival boxes and is arranged alphabetically by folder title. The series includes clemency files, renditions, requisitions, and pardons.

scopecontent.p: The Financial Records are housed in six archival boxes and consist of monthly statements by the Comptroller, Annual Reports, Bonds, the Executive Control Fund and Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.p: The Personal records consist of one box of transitional correspondence (November 1929-January 1930 and January 1934).
